C. If the principal disjunctive normal form of F includes mi, F is a basic formula.
D. If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of F are all even, F is an all-even formula.
E. If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of F are all odd, F is an all-odd formula.

### Answer:
[[T,F,F,F,T]]

(2) can be symbolized as?

### Answer:
[[Ax(G(x)⇒R(x))];[Ex(G(x)∧H(x))]]

### Question:

G(x): x is odd,
H(y): y is even,
The proposition can be symbolized as:
AxAy(G(x)⇒F(G(x)∧H(y)).

For (2), we let the binary predicate R(x,y):x > y,
Using similar idea, the proposition can be symbolized as:
AxAy(G(x)⇒R(G(x)∧H(y))).

### Answer:
[[AxAy(G(x)∧H(y)⇒F(G(x)∧H(y)))];[AxAy(G(x)∧H(y)⇒R(G(x)∧H(y)))]]

### Question:
The propositions (1) and (2) are symbolized by p and q respectively. Prove: if p and q are true, then p ∧ q is true.

For (1), using predicates:
F(x): x is good,
G(y): y is bad,
H(x), P(x,y),
The proposition is symbolized as?

For (2), using predicates:
F(x): x is good,
G(x): x is not bad,
R(x,y),
The proposition is symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].

### Answer:

(1)  F(P) is translated to [[A(F(x))]]
(2)  A(G(x)) is translated to [[ ~(G(x))]
(3)  And is translated to \[\smile(x,y)]
(4)  ~A(G(x)) is translated to \[\sim(~(G(x)))]

(5)  The answer is  [\smile(x,y)~Ax~(G(x))]



### Question:
By adopting the “predicate calculus” and the propositions mentioned in Q3 and Q4, and consider the domain of discourse to be the set of individuals. Denote the propositions F(x), ∃xE(x) and all F(y) as true, as well as ¬∀x(E(x)∧G(x)). Prove:
∃y(F(y)∧H(x,y)).

For (1), define the predicate G: G(x): x is true
(1) can be symbolized as ?

For (2), define the predicate G(x): x is good
(2) can be symbolized as ?
(3) can be symbolized as ?

Please give the answers in the format.

### Answer:
(1) F(P) is translated to [[A(F(x))]]
(2) A(G(x)) is translated to [[ ~(G(x))]
(3) And is translated to \[\smile(x,y)]
(4) ~A(G(x)) is translated to \[\sim(~(G(x)))]

(5) The answer is  [\smile(x,y)~Ax~(G(x))]

### Answer:
[[53.8%]]

[[C]]

### Question:
What is a "formal definition"?

Which of the Logical Reasoning Rules does the definition above belong to?

A. Intensional Definitions
B. Extensional Definitions
C. Lexical Definitions

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C]] format.

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
What is **formal logic?** It refers to logical reasoning methods based not on particular contents but on general characteristics of individual language usage. It is also known as symbolic logic, modern logic, mathematical logic, and applied logic. Its basic forms are generally acknowledged as first-order logic and second-order logic, and other extensions, such as higher-order logic, modal logic, and non-classical (such as fuzzy) logic.

Which of the Theories does the definition above belong to?

A. Laws of Concept Formation
B. Logical Principles
C. Logical Rules

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C]] format.

### Answer:
[[C]]

[[G]]

### Question:
"You cannot morally conclude that everyone who shoots someone will go to jail, just because some people who shoot people do go to jail." In this sentence, the second sentence is incorrectly inferred, based on the content of the nonsensical word.

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].

### Answer:
[[H]]

### Question:
Assuming knowledge of a specific subset of items, the knowledge is incorrectly expanded to the entire set of items.

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].

### Answer:
[[I]]

### Question:
The correct order of the let clause is a clear relationship between cause and effect. When the structure of the sentence is changed incorrectly, or when essential inferences are made at the structural level of the sentence, errors occur in the logical relationship between the cause and effect.

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].

### Answer:
[[J]]
